Is living with HIV a death sentence? 24-year-old Calvin, who contracted HIV at 19, walked us through the moment he discovered he had the virus, the dark place he descended to, and how he plans to live his life from now on. Click the #linkinbio to hear the full episode.

Timestamps in case you wish to skip to the segments:
 - Introduction (0:34)
 - Family and Friends, The first few years into HIV (11:11)
 - Changes in life, Challenges and living with HIV (19:30)

"Shag."
"Intense."
"Fascinating."
"Life-changing."

... were some of the answers when we asked new parliamentarians @carrietancares, @leong.munwai, @destankm and @fahmialimansg to describe their GE2020 experience in 3 words. They also shared what their most memorable moment during the election was.

"There's no doubt that at this very moment, such a policy may not be ideal, but let us come together and agree that this is a principle that we want to roll out."

Jamus Lim gave clarifications on WP's minimum wage idea in Parliament, after he delivered his maiden speech and was met with questions from PAP MPs.

The newly-elected Jamus Lim rose to seek a clarification from Manpower Minister Josephine Teo after the end of her speech. #linkinbio 

Image via CNA.
Sengkang GRC MP Jamus Lim sought clarification from Manpower Minister Josephine Teo on the effectiveness of the recent Employment and S Pass measures.

There will be no physical National Day Rally this year due to Covid-19, and PM Lee will make his "major speech" in Parliament instead. 

From Lee Kuan Yew ranking his leaders, to Goh Chok Tong telling Phua Chu Kang to speak proper English, and Lee Hsien Loong's fishball stick story, here are some of the most iconic moments from previous rallies' speeches by our PMs.

Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo turned emotional while wrapping up a speech on job anxieties among Singaporeans in Parliament on Sept. 1. She said the government understood the concerns about fair treatment and opportunities of PMETs in their 40s and 50s.

This brings the total number of cases in Singapore to 56,852.

There is only one case in the community, who is a Work Pass holder. #linkinbio

Photo from Josephine Teo / FB

Here are all the things you need to know from today's addenda to the President's Address for the new term of government from MTI, MOM, MCI, and MAS and NRF.

Jobs, the economy, 5G, and money.

TL;DR: The ministries' plans for the coming years.

The dormitory conundrum: What does it take to improve the living conditions of migrant workers? And how are Singaporeans contributing to the already complicated situation?

We find out more from Johnathan Cheah, the founder of S11 group. Identified as a cluster on Mar. 30, S11 @ Punggol was the largest Covid-19 cluster in Singapore. The cluster was closed on Aug. 8.

It's the dawn of a new term.

But before it begins, here‚Äôs a recap of the most memorable moments from 13th Parliament of Singapore.

"April 7," says Li Jiang (not his real name), a 43-year-old lorry driver. That's the day his dormitory was shut from the outside world.

"We could still walk along the corridors and go downstairs, but we couldn't leave through that main gate that you just entered," he says.

Twice a day, the dormitory residents had to scan a QR code in their rooms to prove that they were physically there. Failure to do so would result in the cancellation of their work permits and deportation back to their home countries.

Still, Li counts himself luckier than some. Even though he was not able to work during the lockdown, his employer paid him S$750 from April to June, thanks to the Foreign Worker Levy waiver and rebates that he received from the government. #linkinbio

Photo by Joshua Lee

MOM said that they have adopted a multi-layered strategy to prevent a second wave of infections in the cleared dormitories.

This includes implementing safe distancing measures in the dormitories, and grouping migrant workers in the dormitories according to the industry they work in. #linkinbio

Photo from MOM / FB

This year's National Day Anthem Moment was held at 8 different spots across the country, with anchor ministers at each location. Mothership briefly spoke with Ministers Ong Ye Kung and Gan Kim Yong about what their favourite NDP song is, and why.

Filmmaker Royston Tan (@filmr) is the Creative Director for this year's NDP. We showed him some of the memorable moments from past years' parades.

One of them made him cringe.

At a press conference on Aug. 6, Minister Lawrence Wong announced that testing at dormitories would be completed by Aug. 7, with the exception of several standalone blocks which serve as quarantine facilities.

He highlighted that workers who are currently in isolation would need to be tested before leaving quarantine facilities, and that it's possible "volatile case numbers" may come from this group over the next two weeks.

At a press conference on Aug. 6, Director of Medical Services, Associate Professor Kenneth Mak, addressed concerns on the mental health of migrant workers on lockdown in dormitories.

He shared that the taskforce is working with various domains to support migrant workers during the outbreak and are continuously looking at ways to reach out to them and to address their needs.

This brings the total number of cases to 54,555.

MOH said that it expects the daily case counts to be high for the coming days before tapering down as the Inter-agency Taskforce completes the dormitory clearance.

"There were these scenes of people coming together to celebrate. Ideally, they would have practised safe distancing. The people who were there - they know who they are, but I think the moment got the better of them and they perhaps forgot about some of these requirements.

But from the pictures I've seen, all of them were wearing masks. They may not have kept to the rule of 5, and if we can find out who they are, and we have a means to, we might be able to identify and take them to task.

Unfortunately, this appears to have happened in that particular incident, and I would imagine it will not be the end of it. There will be many other incidents where lapses do occur."

Minister Lawrence Wong was responding to a question on whether Singapore should expect a pickup in the number of Covid-19 infections due to the queues and crowds gathering during GE2020.

"I received an email and there was a person who wrote to me, and said that 'Oh, I saw you on TV and you were wearing bright red. Parliament is not a place to wear bright red'. So i said, 'Oh, okay. That's interesting'.
.
So, you know, people watch for these things, and I don't know that they apply the same attention to the male MPs as to the females, but that's the reality."
.
20/20/20 is a video series where we have politicians answer 20 questions by 20 people in their 20s.
.
We got Josephine Teo, Minister of Manpower, to answer questions from youths on the Covid-19 outbreak in migrant worker dormitories, the effect of intense public scrutiny on her, women in politics and whether she still plays basketball like she used to.
.

Here are some of its finest moments.

Gan Soon Peng is a Malaysian working at the Westlite Papan Dormitory, home to about 6,800 migrant workers. When Malaysia announced the MCO on Mar. 18, Gan's commitment to his work compelled him to stay in Singapore, despite not knowing when he would see his family again.

#smolfeature

To prevent possible reinfection and widespread transmission, Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo mentioned on Jun. 1 that MOM has also worked with DSTA and GovTech on the SG Workpass app, which gives workers a green 'cleared' status to enter the workplace once approval has been granted to both their employer and their dormitory.

The minister was there to address the concerns of foreign workers amidst the rising number of confirmed cases found in dormitories.

For example, some food establishments, such as bubble tea stores, have been deemed non-essential, and will have to close after April 21, 11:59pm.

In his address to the nation on Apr. 10, PM Lee also took time to reassure families of foreign workers.

In an address to the nation on Day 4 of the Circuit Breaker period, PM Lee recognised the contributions of the foreign workers and thanked their families. .

"If any of their family members watch my video, let me say this to them: 'We appreciate the work and contributions of your sons, fathers, husbands in Singapore.' On April 5, Singapore reported 120 new cases, the largest single-day increase thus far. Of the 116 local cases, 66 are unlinked, and 32 cases originate from 2 workers' dormitories. [Please see Page 3 for Singapore's Covid-19 situation.]

Around 20,000 workers at S11 Dormitory @ Punggol and Westlite in Toh Guan will be quarantined in their dorms for the next 14 days.
In other dormitories, enhanced precautions will be taken to reduce social interactions between workers and to protect the rest of the community.
Workers in affected dormitories will be given healthcare supplies such as masks, sanitizers and thermometers. They will also be given 3 meals a day.

[BREAKING] This is the first time Singapore reports a three-digit surge in new Covid-19 cases.

116 cases were local transmissions, while four were imported cases.

Two hotspots identified were the foreign worker dormitories of S11 Dormitory @ Punggol and Westlite Toh Guan dormitory.

Photo from Google Maps.

One of the newly confirmed cases (Case 1115) is linked to three previous cases (Cases 510, 511 and 1007), forming a new cluster at The Orange Ballroom. The Orange Ballroom is a wedding and corporate venue located at 845 Geylang Road.

Three other new clusters were also identified on April 4, at Sengei Tengah Lodge, Toh Guan Dormitory and Cochrane Lodge ll.

Image via The Orange Ballroom.

Out of the 75 new cases, six are imported, while 69 are local cases who have no recent travel history. 40 cases are linked to previous cases or clusters, while 29 cases are currently unlinked.

Image via Sungei Tengah Lodge.

Photo from Google Maps

[BREAKING] The amended regulation will affect all workplaces regardless of size, enforcing telecommunication for all the days of the working week.

To ensure compliance, Ministry of Manpower (MOM) officers will be assessing workplaces to see if work from home (WFH) measures are feasible.

Employers found to be flouting the regulations will receive a stop-work order.

Photo from Josephine Teo and MOM/FB.

Four of the confirmed cases are linked to a new cluster at S11 Dormitory @ Punggol (2 Seletar North Link). Seven of the confirmed cases are linked to a new cluster at Wilby Residences (25 Wilby Road). Five of the confirmed cases were also established to be linked to a new cluster at Hero‚Äôs, a sports bar located at 69 Circular Road.

Photo from Google Maps

The Ministry of Manpower will also be limiting the entry or return of work pass holders.

Only those providing essential services like healthcare and transport will be allowed entry or return.

Singapore citizens, Permanent Residents and Long Term Pass holders can still return to Singapore, and will be issued a 14-day Stay-Home Notice.

Photos from Shawn Ang/Unsplash & Guan Zhen Tan.

16 of them breached their Stay-Home Notice or Leave-of-absence (LOA) requirements.

Some were caught working at their workplaces, while others were found leaving their places of residence during the 14-day period.

Photo from Ministry of Manpower‚Äôs Facebook page.

In response to questions about MOM support measures offered to companies with workers affected by the Malaysia lockdown, Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo mentioned that many of such workers are hired by companies that provide healthcare, security, cleaning, waste management and other essential services in Singapore.

Read more in the link in our bio.

Minister of Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing assured local employers that Singapore‚Äôs economic agencies are working to provide temporary accommodation in Singapore for their Malaysian workers who may wish to stay here during Malaysia‚Äôs lockdown.

The economic agencies are working with the companies, dormitory operators and hotels to provide accommodation options for such workers.

Chan also mentioned that companies who need help for their workers‚Äô accommodation can contact and work with said economic agencies and their own trade associations.

Photo by Zheng Zhangxin.

This brings the total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore to 212.

Eight cases were discharged today. The total number of discharged cases is now 105.

Photos from Josephine Teo/FB.

The Ministry of Health announced on Mar. 9 that it will need to prioritise resources at public hospitals in view of the rising number of Covid-19 cases globally and the expected rise in the number of confirmed cases in Singapore.

Therefore, foreigners on short-term visit pass holders who seek treatment for Covid-19 in Singapore will have to pay for their own treatment.

This new ruling has started two days ago on Mar. 7.

Photo from Josephine Teo/FB.
Hand sanitisers have been made available to PUB staff, and every employee has been given a personal thermometer. They are to monitor their daily body temperature and report it twice daily.

Resorts World Sentosa has been monitoring the coronavirus situation and previously stepped up on precautionary measures. Here‚Äôs a statement from their website:

Resorts World Sentosa is monitoring the novel coronavirus situation closely and is taking guidance from the Ministry of Health.

The safety and well-being of our guests and team members are our top priority. We have increased the frequency of disinfection across the resort, especially in areas with high traffic. Hand sanitisers, masks and thermometers are also available at various touchpoints.

Should you feel unwell during your stay or develop respiratory symptoms such as fever, cough or runny nose, please approach our team members immediately for assistance.‚Äù Photo from Google Maps
